DOCNAME: CASE OF VISKUPOVA AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , were born in DATE and DATE respectively . They are siblings . The applicants live in GPE ( GPE ) , and Ms Hermansová also lives in PERSON ( the GPE ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant PERSON owns a share in a plot of land . The applicants each have a share in the estate of their late mother , who owned the remaining share in that plot . The proceedings for the division and distribution of the estate would appear to be still pending .

CARDINAL . The plot has been de facto occupied by the ORG in the guise of a ORG - owned enterprise ( “ the defendant ” ) ; the applicants have been seeking compensation for this occupation ( see below ) .
CARDINAL . The status and functioning of the defendant were regulated by the ORG - owned Enterprises Act ( Law no . ORG . , as amended ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the defendant went into liquidation . According to a publicly available official source , the liquidation process is ongoing .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE amendments ( Laws nos . ORG . and PERSON . respectively ) to the ORG - owned Enterprises Act entered into force .

They provide , inter alia , that the liquidator of a liquidated ORG - owned enterprise has an obligation to publish in ORG ( PERSON vestník ) an announcement on commencement of the liquidation process and to invite those concerned to register their claims within DATE , on pain of extinction of those claims .
They also provide that , by virtue of the commencement of the liquidation process , any enforcement proceedings against the ORG - owned enterprise in question are stayed .
For details , see paragraphs CARDINAL in the “ Relevant domestic law ” below .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG súd ) ruled that the defendant was to pay a sum of money to PERSON and to the applicants’ mother ’s estate by way of compensation for unjustified enrichment arising from the defendant ’s use of the property without valid title .
CARDINAL . NORP The defendant ’s appeal having been declared inadmissible , the judgment became final and binding ( právoplatnosť ) on DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE the applicants contacted the liquidator of the defendant , the municipality where the defendant has its seat and the mayor of that municipality , ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , the police and other public institutions with numerous requests and complaints , seeking to recover the adjudicated amounts .

These efforts included , in particular , a letter of DATE to the liquidator , formulated as a final warning prior to a petition for enforcement , demanding compliance with the judgment in the applicants’ favour ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . However , they met with no success .
CARDINAL . The applicants also made several submissions to the courts seeking judicial enforcement of the judgment .

These resulted , first , in a decision ( uznesenie ) of ORG of DATE to reject the ORG claim , on the ground that it was unclear and , despite the court ’s written request , the applicants had failed to provide further and more specific details .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicants’ subsequent motion of DATE resulted in the opening of enforcement proceedings against the defendant .

CARDINAL . ORG took a number of steps to establish the nature and details of the applicants’ motion . The applicants’ challenge to all of judges of ORG , alleging bias , was also examined and dismissed .

CARDINAL . As established by ORG in its decision of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , there are file - notes in ORG case file , dated CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE , indicating ( i ) that the case file was to be submitted to the judge for determination as to whether the proceedings could continue in view of the provision in the amendments referred to in paragraph CARDINAL above that the proceedings be stayed , and ( ii ) that the proceedings were to be stayed as they interfered with the functions of the liquidator .
On DATE , however , ORG invited the liquidator to report on the progress of the liquidation .

CARDINAL . The proceedings were eventually discontinued on DATE , in the procedural form of a decision ( uznesenie ) , on the ground that , despite the court ’s written request , the applicants had failed to request the transfer of the proceedings to a judicial enforcement officer ( exekútor ) following the entry into force on DATE of an amendment ( Law no . PERSON . ) to LAW ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended – “ the ORG ” ) , under which enforcement of ordinary claims could no longer be carried out by either the courts or judicial enforcement officers , but only by the latter ( for details see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL in the “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) .
No appeal lay against the decision .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE , the applicants had filed a complaint under LAW no . PERSON . , as amended ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) . They contested the length of the proceedings in their enforcement petitions and also invoked , in substance , their right of access to a court .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicants’ complaint was directed against ORG ; its President filed observations in reply on DATE .

It was submitted that under the amendments referred to in paragraph CARDINAL above , there was a statutory bar on the enforcement proceedings , on account of which ORG could not have taken any action at all in the matter .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the applicants’ complaint inadmissible as being manifestly ill - founded .

ORG observed that , pursuant to section CARDINAL ) of the State - owned Enterprises Act , proceedings for the enforcement of financial claims against ORG - owned enterprises in liquidation were stayed by operation of law . This provision also applied , by way of implication , to enforcement proceedings under the ORG . Creditors of such claims should pursue their claims in the liquidation procedure under LAW ) of that LAW and it was the liquidator ’s responsibility under section CARDINALc(CARDINAL)(g ) to settle their claims .

The applicants had thus chosen an incorrect course of action by seeking enforcement of the judgment of DATE as opposed to registering their claim under that judgment with the defendant ’s liquidator . The applicants ought to have known the applicable rules .

CARDINAL . ORG concluded that , for the above - mentioned reasons , there had not been any undue delays in the proceedings before ORG and that there had been no infringement of the applicants’ right of access to a court .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides :

“ CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall decide complaints by natural or legal persons alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms ... unless the protection of such rights and freedoms falls within the jurisdiction of a different court .

CARDINAL . NORP If ORG finds a complaint justified , it shall deliver a decision stating that a person ’s rights or freedoms as set out in paragraph CARDINAL have been violated by a final decision , specific measure or other act and shall quash such a decision , measure or act . If the violation that has been found is the result of a failure to act , ORG may order [ the authority ] which has violated the rights or freedoms to take the necessary action . At the same time it may remit the case to the authority concerned for further proceedings , order that authority to refrain from violating the fundamental rights and freedoms ... or , where appropriate , order those who have violated the rights or freedoms set out in paragraph CARDINAL to restore the situation to that existing prior to the violation .
CARDINAL . NORP In its decision on a complaint ORG may grant appropriate financial compensation to a person whose rights under paragraph CARDINAL have been violated . ”

CARDINAL . NORP Until DATE , if a judgment debtor failed to comply with his or her adjudicated obligation , the creditor had CARDINAL essentially equipollent options of seeking enforcement , by a court under the ORG and by a judicial enforcement officer under LAW ( Law no . ORG . , as amended ) .

CARDINAL . With effect from DATE , Article CARDINAL and other related provisions of the ORG were amended by PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . in that , with certain exceptions that are not relevant to the present case , enforcement of adjudicated claims was henceforth to take place under LAW .

CARDINAL . Under Article QUANTITY of the CPP , as amended by Law no . CARDINAL Coll . , creditors seeking enforcement of their claims before courts had DATE from the entry into force of the amendment to initiate enforcement proceedings under LAW and to inform the enforcement court accordingly . Should they fail to do so , enforcement before the courts was to be discontinued .

CARDINAL . The status of judicial enforcement officers and the procedures for enforcement by judicial enforcement officers are governed by LAW . Under its LAW , a judicial enforcement officer is a person designated and entrusted by the ORG with obtaining forcible compliance with judicial and other decisions .
CARDINAL . The Act regulates the status and functioning of ORG - owned enterprises ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Law no . PERSON . amended the LAW with effect from DATE . It introduced , inter alia , sections CARDINALa to GPE , providing for detailed rules concerning the liquidation of ORG - owned enterprises .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINALc(CARDINAL)(a ) of the amended LAW provides :

“ In the course of liquidation the liquidator has an obligation to publish in ORG a notice on commencement of the entry of the [ ORG - owned ] enterprise into liquidation , together with a call for all creditors and other persons and bodies which are concerned by the enterprise ’s entry into liquidation , to register their claims or other rights within a period which can not be shorter than DATE from the enterprise ’s entry into liquidation , failing which [ such claims or rights ] become extinct ” .
CARDINAL . Under Section CARDINALc(CARDINAL)(g ) of the amended Act :
“ In the course of liquidation the liquidator has a duty to settle obligations and claims ” .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINALc(CARDINAL ) of the amended Act provided :
“ Liquidation of a [ ORG - owned ] enterprise can not be interrupted by other proceedings under special statute [ such as , for example , enforcement proceedings under LAW ] . ”
CARDINAL . Law no . PERSON . amended the LAW with effect from DATE . Among other things , it amended the wording of Section CARDINALc(CARDINAL ) of the LAW as follows :
“ Proceedings under special statute [ such as , for example , enforcement proceedings under LAW ] shall be stayed by the [ ORG - owned ] enterprise ’s entry into liquidation . ”
CARDINAL . Section DATE ( CARDINAL ) of the Act was subsequently renumbered as section CARDINALc ( CARDINAL) , without any change in its wording .

CARDINAL . Under LAW ( d ) of the ORG , civil proceedings may be reopened where the ORG has found a violation of the requesting party ’s Convention rights and where any serious consequences arising from the violation have not been adequately redressed by the award of just satisfaction . In principle , however , only proceedings which have been concluded by means of a judgment ( rozsudok ) can be reopened .
